messages.content:
Hello,
I'm working on a game and I would like a user to be able to obtain a token each time they win a game, so I was thinking of using the timestamp of the start of the game and the player's key to uniquely identify the game and rely on it to prevent a user from submitting the same proof several times to obtain several tokens, how to accomplish this?
Generate a contract with the information? Use actions?
I would recommend generating JWT tokens. It is the example: https://github.com/dfstio/minanft/blob/master/src/api/jwt.ts

embeds.title: minanft/src/api/jwt.ts at master Â· dfstio/minanft
embeds.description: Mina NFT backend, API and telegram bot with AI support (ChatGPT, DALL-E and Whisper models) - dfstio/minanft

messages.content: Then, you can use it your proof hash of JWT
It's just an expiracy policy, so how to prevent sending the same information 2 times in a row if the token has not expired it will be accepted.
You can use MerkleTree exclusion proof
So I need to create a merkle tree and store it ?
Yes, in this solution, you should do it. Still, you can keep it very small by keeping in this tree only proof hashes that were presented in the last hour (if you set JWT expiry one hour)
Ok thank you, I will check if I can manage an other solution fully onchain, I don't want to deal with external backup

Please let me know if you will find a solution that allows to check for exclusion by using exclusively on-chain data. I doubt it exists, you will need some off-chain storage for it.

What you can do if you don't want to keep data structures yourself is to use events as data storage. Each event can keep up to 100 Fields, and you can access this storage in UI by querying the archive node. You cannot access this storage from the contract, but you can keep in the contract state Merkle Tree root and reconstruct this Merkle Tree each time you call the contract from events data.
I will try my idea not related to merkle proof, If I work I will share it with you

It's work, it's more an hack than a real solution, I use token balance as storage, I can use my main token to do that if I use decimal as storage, but I created my solution as a POC, you can implement it for anything and extend these possibilities

https://github.com/youtpout/zkapp-ui/blob/main/contracts/src/tictacsign.ts

embeds.title: zkapp-ui/contracts/src/tictacsign.ts at main Â· youtpout/zkapp-ui
embeds.description: Contribute to youtpout/zkapp-ui development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: @Youtpout creative solution! You could also set a certain state field on the winner's token account

Great solution, you've just ported the Solidity map to Mina protocol, very cool!

I also use mint in my project, but for different purposes: verifying NFT metadata. Each NFT has a version number, and if metadata is successfully verified, the token amount equal to the version number is minted.
If NFT metadata is changed later, the version number is automatically increased, and verification is automatically revoked, verification needs to be done again for new metadata:

https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/src/plugins/badge.ts#L110

embeds.title: minanft-lib/src/plugins/badge.ts at master Â· dfstio/minanft-lib
embeds.description: MinaNFT TypeScript/JavaScript integration library. Contribute to dfstio/minanft-lib development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: It seems like we should ask @gregor to create the possibility of map structures in the Mina Protocol to make this solution official)))
Do you mean there is also an 8 Fields account state on the token account that we can access? How Permissions are set for changing this state?
Yes there's 8 field state also on non-zkapp/token accounts. All accounts are the same in Mina
By default, all permissions on an account are set to signature

Oh we have 8 fields by account ?
So I can store data in account created between user and tokenId ?
Yes
Please note that init() is not being called for the TokenAccount contract, so state initialization should be done in Token.mint()

Great work in figuring stuff out @DFST, as always!

To add a bit more colour, what your example (https://discord.com/channels/484437221055922177/1171202435663007804/1172176409305813033) is using is the "raw" account update API which corresponds 1:1 to the transaction that is being written, without any nice usability added by o1js on top.

What's missing to make the state API match other account fields is to add state here somewhere: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/5ca43684e98af3e4f348f7b035a0ad7320d88f3d/src/lib/precondition.ts#L82
(Back when I implemented this, I didn't think state was important because we already have the custom API on SmartContract, and I didn't consider the need to set state on other accounts)
If you will revise this, could you please also consider the possibility of adding get() functions to zkappUri, tokenSymbol, and other fields that have only set() functions
And if I deploy the SmartContract to the token account, I can use the same nice usability api; I can't use it only before deployment
no, we can only provide get() functions on fields where the protocol allows preconditions
Now understand the logic

messages.content:
@DFST 
If we can deploy a  `SmartContract`  to a token account, then how does the `this.token` API work for the TokenAccount?
Does it operates on the original token created in the `Token` smart contract?
Or does it give a completely new token?

If I am understanding it correct, the `this.token` api of `TokenAccount` will be isolated to this token itself. This means that, I should be able to implement a token hierarchy.. right? Something similar to ERC1155.
How is this.token.id generated for a smart contract

Hi @0xKriss1897 !
You have raised a very interesting question. I've tried to test it, and the results are:
- All tokenId are different so that you can do a chain of Token accounts
- I was able to deploy the chain of Token accounts to the local blockchain and TestWorld2

So, in theory, it can work, but you should take into account two issues:
- You should do all calls only through the main contracts; otherwise, the calls will probably fail, i.e., if you have the main Token1 contract that deploys the Token2 contract that deploys the Token3 contract to call Token3, you need to call the Token1 contract method that calls Token 2 contract method that calls Token3 contract method (see mint2 method example in my test code)
- There is a bug that can prevent you from accessing two token accounts in one call. I don't know the workarounds and am temporarily disabling the MinaNFT contract code parts that do such calls.

Given the limitations above, I'm not sure that you will be able to call Token3 method - it needs to be tested.

My test code:
https://github.com/dfstio/minanft-lib/blob/master/experimental/token_account5.test.ts
Transactions on TestWorld2 that deploy chain token contracts 
https://minascan.io/testworld/tx/5JudQgY14uihXuQJ23ho4JPn4D2wMVQoCxCCN9Qusa9K6m9AP4Gs?type=zk-tx
https://minascan.io/testworld/tx/5JvQjybS6kvt9m5mSzdriBrnAknEgCmJJffuasUDSDJQs16qvhsT?type=zk-tx
https://minascan.io/testworld/tx/5JunT8cCXEqGxiGsKqq1deMuxDYX9kQe3KVVbFCizrhPHEPmHfkv?type=zk-tx
Bug issue:
https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/issues/1245
Got it. Thanks for trying it out.. Iâll also do the same around my use case.
Thanks for posting the issue btw @DFST. It seems related to a very long-standing issue and I'll look at it after the holiday break!
